metadata.case_name: Bhagwantrao Shivaji Patel v. Vishwasrao Patel & Ors.

facts.text: Lands in suit comprised in six survey numbers in village Nawabag, a jagir village in Ellichpur taluq of Berar.

Four families of Patels (Dongre, Rokade, Raut, Ingle) held Patel office in rotation of ten years each. Concerned with Rokade family: Shivajirao had sons Amrit and Bhagwantrao (appellant). Vishwasrao (respondent No.1) son of Amrit.
Shivajirao died in 1886, Amrit died in 1920.
Partition in 1923 between appellant (Bhagwantrao) and respondent No.1 (Vishwasrao); appellant claimed patelki inam lands allotted to his share.
Shivajirao, Amrit, and Vishwasrao worked as Patel in turn.

In 1935, special officer appointed to prepare record of rights for Nawabag jagir; report led to enquiries holding appellant not entitled to patelki inam lands, which were emoluments for working Patel (Vishwasrao). Deputy Commissioner ordered resumption from appellant and regrant to Vishwasrao.
Appellant appealed; Commissioner set aside eviction order, maintained status quo pending Government orders.
On December 19, 1941, Financial Commissioner held working Patel entitled to full emoluments, set aside Commissioner's order, restored Deputy Commissioner's.
Appellant filed suit in 1942 (Civil Suit No.1 of 1943) claiming Government had no jurisdiction to resume/regrant lands, orders null/void; sought possession and mesne profits.
Amendment to plaint: plots 2/1A and 9/1A ceased to be patelki inam, became private family property; no right to resume.
Trial Judge (Civil Judge First Class, Ellichpur) dismissed suit on December 20, 1945.
First Additional District Judge, Amraoti decreed suit in Civil Appeal No.85-A of 1946 on February 3, 1947.

Nagpur High Court in Second Appeal No.169 of 1947 allowed appeal on November 27, 1951, set aside District Judge's decree, restored trial court's; held lands service inam, resumable under Patels and Patwaris Law 1900 and s.190 Berar Land Revenue Code 1928.
Certificate under Art.133(1)(c) granted by High Court for SC appeal.
Berar ceded by Nizam in 1853; Inam Rules 1859; Rule 1: inams held 40 years before cession valid.
Inam entry Ex.P-1 dated August 31, 1866: Nawabag jagir granted by Kings of Delhi to Shah Abdul Huq, confirmed by Nizam 1757; 262 bighas patelki inam at 1.5 bighas per netan.
Kararnama Ex.P-9A October 24, 1771: Dispute between jagirdars and patels; Nazim confirmed 1.5 bighas per netan patelki inam per old usage.
Rokade family held about 11 plots, 50 acres of patelki inam.
Pre-1904: Some jagirdars alienated lands; half jagir resumed 1904-05; survey nos.1-21,40-45 patelki in resumed portion (incl. 2/1A,9/1A made Khalsa, assessed); 22-39 in jagir portion unassessed.
1917 resumption: alienated jagir lands regranted to jagirdars, not made Khalsa; jagirdars claimed patelki lands.
Government letter August 28, 1922: Excluded 25 acres 15 gunthas khalsa and 24 acres 30 gunthas inam portions; recorded as patelki huq inam of Amrit Shivaji Patel.
Other Patel families' claims rejected except Amritrao.
Lands originally in CP & Berar, then Madhya Pradesh, now Bombay.

legal_issues.text: True nature of patelki huq inam lands: grant by way of remuneration/emoluments for Patel's office, or grant to patelki family burdened with service (joint family lands subject to partition)?
Whether grant made by jagirdar or sovereign authority; applicability of Inam Rules 1859, Patels and Patwaris Law 1900.
Whether Government had jurisdiction to resume/regrant lands to working Patel (Vishwasrao).
Special claim re survey nos. 2/1A and 9/1A: ceased to be inam, private property.
Claim of title by adverse possession.

petitioner_arguments.text: Rights in lands were of ownership subject to family member rendering service; grant of land burdened with service.
Grant made by jagirdar, not sovereign; Inam Rules/Patels Law 1900 inapplicable.
Even if Rules/Law applied, retained hereditary rights in lands.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Inam Rules V, VI; Patels and Patwaris Law 1900 s.3

petitioner_arguments.text: 1922 orders conferred no new right, deprived no subsisting right; no resumption right.
Plots 2/1A, 9/1A ceased to be inam post-1904-05 resumption, became private via suits/decrees.

respondent_arguments.text: Lands granted as remuneration/emoluments for services by Patel; service inam resumable/regrantable to working Patel.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Patels and Patwaris Law 1900; Berar Land Revenue Code s.190

respondent_arguments.text: Patelki inam independent of jagir; ancient grant by sovereign confirmed.

court_reasoning.text: Patelki inam originated as sovereign grant (Nazim 1771, Inam entry 1866); from year to year in lieu of services, binding on jagirdars.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Independent of jagir, evidenced by 1906-08 appointments, 1908 order, 1917-22 proceedings.

court_reasoning.text: Character: emoluments for office, not family land burdened with service; disputes over remuneration, statements by Amrit/appellant confirm.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Kararnama 1771, Inam 1866, Amrit's statements, 1917-22 proceedings show lands as wages.

court_reasoning.text: Aliens/resumptions by Govt show no free alienation; rotation under s.3 Patels Law doesn't alter emoluments to working Patel.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.9 Patels Law: emoluments solely to holder.

court_reasoning.text: Inam Rules don't support share claim: service not discontinued; Rules VI(8), XI, XIV prohibit division/shares.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No interference to compel sharing service grants.

court_reasoning.text: Patels Law s.9-11,20: emoluments to holder only, no attachment/sale/assignment, civil court bar.
Berar LRC s.190: power to forfeit alienated/service lands, regrant on conditions; s.192 bars civil suits.
Plots 2/1A,9/1A: treated as part of homogeneous patelki inam in 1922; decrees not for these plots.
No adverse possession against Govt; possession permissive as emoluments.

holdings.text: Patelki huq inam lands are grant of emoluments for Patel's office by sovereign, independent of jagir, resumable/regrantable to working Patel by revenue authorities.
Inam Rules 1859, Patels and Patwaris Law 1900, Berar LRC 1928 s.190 apply; no hereditary share right independent of service performance.
Government had jurisdiction to resume/regrant; civil courts barred.
No special claim for plots 2/1A,9/1A; no adverse possession.

precedents_cited.relevance: High Court relied on; distinction noted for Berar patelki vs Madras karnam lands.
Jagir case; partition possible unless impartible/service conditions.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mir Subhan Ali v. Imami Begum
precedents_cited.relevance: Inam devolution per Rules/sanad; not service grant.
Distinction: office remunerated by land (resumable) vs land burdened with service.
Inam certificate allowed sharer possession; specific terms.

statutes_cited.name: Inam Rules 1859 (Berar)
statutes_cited.relevance: Settlement of inams; service inams not divisible, resumable if service discontinued; patelki confirmed valid.

statutes_cited.name: Patels and Patwaris Law, 1900 (Berar)
statutes_cited.relevance: Rotation of office; emoluments solely to holder; no attachment/sale/assignment; civil court bar.

statutes_cited.name: Berar Land Revenue Code, 1928
statutes_cited.relevance: Forfeiture/resumption of service/alienated lands; civil court bar on revenue matters.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upholding Nagpur High Court judgment that patelki huq inam lands are service emoluments resumable by revenue authorities and regrantable to the working Patel; appellant's claims rejected.

key_quotes.text: "the grant was from year to year in lieu of patelki services and was binding on the jagirdars who agreed to be bound by it."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Confirms annual emoluments nature from 1771 kararnama.

key_quotes.text: "the lands were given in lieu of emoluments or remuneration."
key_quotes.speaker: petitioner

key_quotes.text: "Section 9 ... the emoluments appertaining to the office of the patel ... shall be enjoyed solely by the person for the time being holding the office."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key statutory bar to sharing emoluments.
